IGNITE
A 2 WEEK-LONG
ENTREPRENEURSHIP PROGRAM
Agenda

9:00 | Settle in
9:15 | Introduction to Five One Labs and Ignite
10:05 | Break
10:20 | “Yes, and…” icebreaker 
10:35 | Design thinking overview
10:50 | Design Sprint

----

9:00 | Settle in
People arrive
Mingle 
Offer people cookies, fruit, tea, coffee, etc…
Answer questions 

9:15 | Day’s Intro + Welcome
Introduce yourself and welcome everyone!
Welcome everyone, we are so happy you can join us today for the first day of Ignite! Today is all about getting to know each other, understanding the program, and setting the foundations for the next two weeks as you learn more about the market and your customers needs!
1



LET'S GET TO KNOW EACH OTHER
 Name?
 Where you are from?
 Tell us your idea.
 What’s your superpower?
10 minutes: Share

Introductions:
Before we get started, I would like to introduce myself and get to know all of you a bit better. Let's quickly go around the room and share:
Your name,
Where you are from,
Tell us a little bit about your idea. 
And finally, if you had a superpower, what would it be (flying, reading minds, shape shifting, etc…)?

The trainers should start first. Then, go around the room so each person can introduce themselves.
2

09:00 am 		Welcome + Introductions!
09:30 am		Five One Labs & Ignite
10:30 am		Design Sprint 
12:00 pm		Group Lunch
01:30 pm		User Research 
04:30 pm		Wrap up
AGENDA
1 minute: Lecture

Agenda: Now that we all know each other a little better, let’s get into the agenda for the day. 
This morning we will spend some time understanding Five One Labs, the program, and what exactly you will be doing over the two weeks. This will be an opportunity to clarify any questions you still have and give you some insights on what is in store ahead through a design sprint!
Group Lunch: At 12:00 we will take a break and get lunch together. 
This afternoon we will come back and get into user research. This is the first major session we will have. Here we will define our research plan for the next few weeks! Tell us a little bit about your idea, what problem does it solve? Finally, we will wrap up around 4:30!

3

YES, AND….
15 minutes: Icebreaker 

2 minutes: Explain the activity
Trainers should conduct the “YES, AND…” Icebreaker
Make teams of about 3-5
State a problem or ask the group for a problem 
For example:
It’s a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
It is so hot outside, how can I get to and from work without sweating or ever feeling the heat?
 
5 minutes: “No” technique:
You have 2 minutes to generate different crazy ideas to solve that problem. Generate as many as possible. But there is a rule! When one member in the team says an idea another one must say “no!” and come up with a completely different idea. This goes on and on until the 2 minutes are up. You have to do this quickly, let's see how many crazy ideas we will get.
For example: It’s a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
Use an umbrella!
No! Build a tunnel to go directly inside!
No! make a waterproof suit that covers your whole body!
No! Build an overpass that my taxi/bus will drop me off under!
No! Have a drone float above my head to prevent water from touching me.
No!.....
[2 minutes pass] Time is done!
Ask them about the different crazy ideas they came up with.
 
5 minutes: Now let’s try “yes and”: 
You have 2 minutes again, and this time someone says an idea, and then someone else in the group must say “yes”, and add a feature to grow the idea to make the idea bigger. Is it clear? Let's do it
For example: It’s a rainy day and I want to get into five one labs without getting wet, how can I do that?
Build a tunnel to go directly inside from where you get dropped off!
Yes! And have heat inside to keep you warm on cold days
Yes! And the heat system is controlled by an app on your phone that you can use to control the temperature where you are walking
Yes! And …..
Ask them about the different crazy ideas they came up with

3 minutes: Review + recap
Ask them which one did they like and why? (yes and or no method)
Then explain “yes and” is good because it’s positive, and it feels good when your friends agree with your idea, right? And you can build on top of it to create really good and complete ideas. You can go deeper and come up with things that you normally wouldn’t have discovered.
“No” is also good, as it generates a wide variety of ideas. And in real life when you talk about your idea to someone not everybody is positive and will like your idea. Sometimes you have to say no!

Recap: As a rule at Five One Labs, we try to use the “yes and” method. We want to build off and support each other.

4

Design Sprint!
1 minutes: Lecture

Ok great! I hope you had some fun and got to know the people sitting around you a little bit more. 
We are now going to get into the first design thinking session of Ignite, the Design Sprint! We’ll think about creative solutions that are not just effective but also mindful of resources. But first, we will give you a little introduction to the Design curriculum and an overview of the design thinking methodology.
5


Feb. 2, 2020:		      Introduction to Design Thinking
Feb. 2, 2020:		      User Research
Feb. 16, 2020:	      Define the Problem
Feb. 20, 2020:		Creativity and Ideation
 
 

DESIGN THINKING SCHEDULE
April 1
Intro to design thinking
April 1
April 7
April 8
User research
Define the problem
Creativity and ideation
3 minutes: Lecture

Quickly give an overview of the 4 Design sessions they will have over the next two weeks. 
Introduction to Design Thinking: We will focus on giving you a good understanding of design thinking and the human centered design process today through a design sprint. Starting this afternoon, we will talk about applying the Design Thinking methodology to your business.
User Research: We will go into creating a research plan for you to deeply understand your customers and their needs.
Reframe: Define the Problem: We will take all of our research, and clearly define the problem for your different customer types.
Creativity and Ideation: Finally, we will generate solutions to your customers problems. Some of them might be your current ideas, but we hope to generate a wide variety of ideas that could all be potential solutions. 
6

2 minutes: Discussion

Ask: What is design thinking? Why is it useful?
Potential answers:
A way to take a messy problem and turn it into something much more clear and more ordered
A way to enhance your creativity, build stronger, more innovative solutions
To build a deeper understanding of people 
Human centered, iterative, collaborative, experiential 
There is a bias towards action
You should work to embody these mindsets throughout the rest of this sprint

increased creativity
stronger solutions

A way to take a messy problem and turn it into something much more clear and more ordered
A way to enhance your creativity, build stronger, more innovative solutions
To build a deeper understanding of people 
Human centered, iterative, collaborative, experiential 
There is a bias towards action

8

CC, BY-NC-ND, ⓒ Joe Thorn
Discussion: 5 minutes 

Ask: Take a look at this photo – who can tell me what this girl needs? (gather responses and write them on the board separating verbs and nouns without telling the group you are doing so)
Potential answers (nouns):
She needs a book
A ladder
A taller chair
Shoes
Her parents
Etc… 

Potential answers (verbs)
Be independent
Gain knowledge
Learn information
To explore
Etc…

5 minutes: Recap 
If you define needs as nouns, then there are only so many ways you can solve the problem – For example, instead of saying ‘we need more electricity,’ you could say ‘we need to reduce energy waste,’ which opens up more creative possibilities.
If you describe the need as a verb, you give yourself exponentially more options – For example, if you say “she needs to learn”, there are so many ways you can do this and you allow for countless possibilities:
Get a teacher
Use a book
Use an online learning app
Watch a video online
Practice something
Etc… 
During the activity, we’ll ask you to keep this in mind as you’re getting to know your partner
9

Define a clear problem
Build your product
Find the best ideas
Test and improve
Undertsand your customers
DESIGN THINKING: A NON-LINEAR PROCESS
TEST
PROTOTYPE
IDEATE
DEFINE
EMPATHIZE
5 minutes: Lecture + discussion

Over the course of this program, you will experience the Design Thinking process and apply it to your businesses. 
The first step is to empathize with your user. Put yourself in their shoes and explore how they are experiencing the problem that your business idea is solving. Speak to customers and listen to their stories. 
After we explore our customers experiences, challenges, and high points, we will reframe that information and define the problem. What is the core challenge that our customers are facing?
Once we have a clearly stated problem statement, we go into ideation. What are all the possible solutions for that customer’s problem? We want a wide variety of potential solutions. Don’t be stuck in your idea!
Next, we take a few of these ideas, build them, and test it out! By prototyping and testing frequently, we are able to save time and money while developing a product that the customers really want!

That is the design thinking process. It appears linear, and in some ways it can be. However, keep in mind that it is not intended to be a one way process. You can go back and forth on this depending on your needs.  
Ask: Can someone give me an example of how this might not be a linear process? How might someone using the design thinking methodology move around in a way that is out of order?
Potential answers:
Maybe you are trying to define a clear problem, but you realize you did not gather enough information, go back and get more! Talk to more people
Maybe you finished testing your prototype, you are going to want to bring it back to the customers and listen to how they are experiencing the product. You will continuously go through the process several times. 

Transition: Design is all about being experiential, so let’s get started!


LET’S GO!
< 1 minute: Lecture

Now we are going to do a design sprint and go through the whole Design Thinking process in just 1 hour!
11

2 minutes: Lecture

Frame the activity and put the entrepreneurs in a situation.
So let me start by giving you a problem. I face this problem every day and I’m sure many of you face it as well. 

Problem: Every morning I wake up exhausted. I dread getting out of my warm bed to go to work in the morning. 

My challenge for all of you is to redesign the morning routine to solve this problem (even if you like the morning, redesign it to make it even better).  There is one caveat here, you are not redesigning the morning routine for yourself, you are designing it for your partner. 

Everyone should now get into pairs. 


12

INTERVIEW
8 minutes: Activity

4 minutes each: Interview Part 1
Learn as much as you can about the other person’s morning routine
What was their favorite part? What could be improved? 

13

DIG DEEPER
6 minutes: Activity

3 minutes each: Dig Deeper
Time to dig deeper – go for emotion
Ask why 5 times
What’s the underlying reason they do things? 

14

DEFINE
5 minutes: Activity

3 minutes: Capture Findings (alone)
Define needs as verbs 
Pinpoint surprising insights, that you’ll keep in mind as you’re developing a solution

2 minutes: Reframe (alone)
Write the challenge you are going to address vis a vis your partner
Write out your point of view: “my partner needs to do get to work on time, keeping in mind that she has three kids that she needs to feed and get to school on time as well”

15

BRAINSTORM
13 minutes: Activity

5 minutes: Brainstorm (alone)
Come up with at least 5 creative ways to solve this problem
Draw, sketch, or write out what you think these solutions would look like
Make sure they’re all very different from each other
Push yourself to think outside the box. 
Use creative constraints to help your imagination. What it it had to be a physical object, what it it had to be made from recycled materials, what it if had to be made entirely with local materials?
Go for volume – generate as many ideas as you can (if you have more than five, write them down anyway)

4 minutes each: Share ideas with your partner
16

BUILD
8 minutes: Activity

Build a prototype!! (alone)
 Offer a diverse range of materials, encourage resource consciousness by providing local, recycled, and green materials.
 Send the entrepreneurs in the other room where prototyping supplies are laid out for them.
 How might this solution fit into the context of your partner’s life? 
 Improve and build out the concept you talked about
17

FEEDBACK
20 minutes: Activity

6 minutes: Feedback (3 mins each) 
Remember, your idea is not precious, feedback is just a way to learn more
Generate more feedback
Write down how they feel about it
Watch how they use it, misuse it, what mistakes are they making, what doesn’t make sense, etc
Write down one new idea, one big question from feedback. Could your solution work with fewer resources or less waste?
 
10 minutes: Debrief 
How did discussing and gathering feedback from the person change how your final solution looks?
If you had to make it for yourself, would it look the same as it did for your partner?
Who ended up with something their partner really liked? Why? What about it stood out? 
What would you change in your next iteration?
What part was most uncomfortable? What was most natural? 
How was it as a user interacting with the prototype? 

18

TEST
PROTOTYPE
IDEATE
DEFINE
EMPATHIZE
5 minutes: Wrap up

Briefly explain again how they just went through the whole design thinking process in under an hour
Explain that during Ignite, we will go through the first 3 steps, and then the incubator we will do the last 2 steps
Wrap up for lunch

**Highlighting key activities**

**Merging climate resilience**

I’m listing specific module slides to pinpoint key activities. Then, I’m suggesting adding climate questions to interviews to enhance solutions with sustainability and climate resilience.

**Task 1: Module Summary**  
This user research module centers on creating detailed user personas and empathy maps to uncover customers’ motivations, challenges, and desires. Through interviews, “dig deeper” exercises, and empathy-focused discussions, participants learn to frame problems around real user needs and explore solutions that resonate with their target audience. As a result, entrepreneurs gain clarity on user pain points and can iterate more effectively toward solutions that address genuine market gaps.

---

**Task 2: Climate Integration Analysis**

| **Location**       | **Current Activity**                                                    | **Suggested Change**                                                                                                                                                                                                       | **Reasoning (Business Impact)**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |
|--------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Slide 13: “Interview”**  | Participants interview each other about morning routines to build empathy and understand needs.                          | Add a prompt about environmental/climate factors in the user’s routine (e.g., “How do seasonal changes or extreme weather affect your routine?”).                                                                           | **Benefit**: Encourages participants to uncover climate-related obstacles or opportunities early, which can guide solutions that are more robust and relevant to local climate challenges.                                                                        |
| **Slide 14: “Dig Deeper”** | Participants ask “why” repeatedly to surface deeper motivations and underlying causes.                                      | Incorporate a “green lens” question: “How might environmental constraints or resource availability shape the user’s underlying needs?”                                                                                     | **Benefit**: By exploring climate-related motivations or barriers, solutions can be designed to reduce resource risks, improve local reputation, and potentially lower operational costs by aligning with sustainability trends.                                   |
| **Slide 15: “Brainstorm”** | Individuals generate a variety of potential solutions and then share them with partners.                                   | Ask participants to add at least one “climate resilience constraint” to each idea (e.g., local materials, energy efficiency, circular economy).                                                                             | **Benefit**: Embeds sustainability into early ideation, leading to business ideas that can appeal to climate-conscious customers and potentially tap into green financing or local environmental incentives.                                                        |
| **Slide 16: “Build”**      | Participants build prototypes of their top ideas using available materials.                                                | Encourage the use of upcycled or locally sourced materials for prototyping. Provide a brief overview of low-impact materials suitable for local conditions.                                                                   | **Benefit**: Demonstrates hands-on how to incorporate climate-aware design. Using upcycled or local resources can reduce waste, foster local partnerships, and create products that resonate with eco-conscious customers.                                           |
| **Slide 17: “Feedback”**   | Participants receive peer/user feedback and refine prototypes.                                                             | Introduce climate impact feedback questions: “Could this solution work effectively under more extreme weather?” or “How could we reduce its carbon footprint?”                                                               | **Benefit**: Gathering feedback on environmental resilience helps refine products for greater durability and resource efficiency, strengthening market appeal and positioning the solution as climate-ready.                                                        |
| **Slide 18: “Debrief”**    | The group discusses challenges, successes, and takeaways from the design sprint process.                                   | Facilitate a short reflection on sustainability lessons learned: “What climate-related assumptions did you challenge or validate? How could your idea scale or adapt if climate conditions worsen?”                         | **Benefit**: Encourages participants to think about long-term environmental risks and market opportunities, positioning their businesses for resilience, future growth, and potential sustainability funding or partnerships.                                       |

---

By integrating these climate considerations at each stage—interview, deeper inquiry, brainstorming, prototyping, and feedback—you help participants embed resilience into their user research. This not only addresses local climate challenges but also equips entrepreneurs to design adaptable, future-proof solutions with tangible business advantages.

Here is a detailed scoring analysis of the module based on the provided rubrics, identifying gaps and suggesting implementation priorities.  

---

### **Module Scoring Analysis**

| **Skill Element**            | **Current Score** | **Target Score** | **Evidence & Gaps** | **Implementation Priority** | **Suggested Implementation** |
|------------------------------|------------------|------------------|----------------------|----------------------------|------------------------------|
| **Business Model Resilience** | 2 | 4 | Some elements of market understanding are present, but no direct integration of resilience strategies. | **High** (Core to module + Easy to implement) | Introduce exercises on market shocks, resource risks, and business continuity planning under climate-related stress. |
| **Risk Management & Scenario Planning** | 1 | 4 | No formal discussion on environmental risks or adaptive strategies. | **High** (Major gap + Critical for climate resilience) | Embed a session on climate risk mapping, identifying potential risks in user personas, and planning for business continuity. |
| **Sustainability as Value Proposition** | 2 | 4 | Basic awareness present but lacks direct application in product/service ideation. | **Medium** (Important but requires content changes) | Modify brainstorming and prototyping activities to include a “green lens” on product differentiation. |
| **Triple Bottom Line Thinking** | 1 | 3 | No explicit focus on environmental and social impact considerations. | **Medium** (Relevant but not central) | Add a debrief exercise reflecting on economic, social, and environmental benefits of proposed solutions. |
| **Stakeholder Engagement** | 2 | 3 | Encourages customer research but does not integrate environmental stakeholders. | **Medium** (Needs adaptation in exercises) | Expand stakeholder analysis to include sustainability-focused actors (e.g., local policymakers, eco-conscious consumers). |
| **Green Market Understanding** | 1 | 4 | No inclusion of local green business case studies. | **High** (Core to module + Easy to implement) | Introduce local case studies on climate-friendly startups, showing demand trends for sustainable products/services. |
| **Sustainable Product Design** | 2 | 4 | Some ideation on eco-friendly materials, but not structured. | **High** (Core to module + Directly applicable) | Provide a resource guide on sustainable design principles and require teams to integrate eco-conscious materials in prototypes. |
| **Climate-Smart Growth** | 1 | 3 | No explicit link between business growth and environmental constraints. | **Medium** (Valuable but not core) | Add scenario discussions on how climate change affects business scaling (e.g., water shortages affecting manufacturing). |
| **Systems Thinking** | 2 | 4 | Some indirect elements through design thinking, but lacks explicit framing. | **Medium** (Important but requires framing shift) | Introduce a systems mapping exercise showing how businesses interact with environmental and economic systems. |
| **Critical Thinking** | 3 | 4 | Strong problem-framing exercises but could benefit from deeper sustainability reflection. | **Low** (Minor gap) | Integrate a structured debate on sustainability trade-offs in product design. |
| **Problem Framing** | 4 | 5 | Well-integrated into design thinking but missing climate-specific applications. | **Medium** (High existing foundation) | Require participants to reframe problems with a climate resilience focus (e.g., water scarcity, extreme heat, pollution). |
| **Futures Literacy** | 1 | 4 | No discussion of long-term climate trends affecting businesses. | **High** (Major gap + Critical future skill) | Add scenario planning exercises exploring how businesses adapt to climate change over 10+ years. |
| **Adaptability** | 3 | 4 | Built into design thinking but could use explicit emphasis on environmental resilience. | **Medium** (Enhance existing exercises) | Introduce rapid iteration rounds where teams respond to climate-related challenges affecting their ideas. |
| **Exploratory Thinking** | 3 | 4 | Encourages creativity but not in relation to sustainability constraints. | **Medium** (Expand on existing methods) | Add structured constraints (e.g., “design a zero-waste prototype” challenge). |
| **Collective Action** | 1 | 3 | No focus on community-driven sustainability efforts. | **Medium** (Relevant but requires new content) | Incorporate case studies of cooperative climate initiatives and crowd-sourced innovation. |
| **Individual Initiative** | 4 | 5 | Strong emphasis on self-driven entrepreneurship, but could integrate personal accountability for sustainability. | **Low** (Already well integrated) | Encourage personal sustainability pledges and action plans for climate-positive business models. |

---

### **Key Priorities**
1. **High-Priority Elements (Easy to Implement, Major Gaps)**
   - **Risk Management & Scenario Planning** → Introduce climate risk exercises.  
   - **Green Market Understanding** → Add local case studies.  
   - **Business Model Resilience** → Teach adaptation strategies.  
   - **Sustainable Product Design** → Structure eco-conscious design tasks.  
   - **Futures Literacy** → Run long-term climate impact exercises.  

2. **Medium-Priority Elements (Important but Needs Content Revision)**
   - **Sustainability as Value Proposition** → Modify ideation exercises.  
   - **Stakeholder Engagement** → Expand to environmental actors.  
   - **Problem Framing** → Require climate-focused redefinitions.  
   - **Systems Thinking** → Add mapping exercises.  

3. **Low-Priority Elements (Already Present, Minor Gaps)**
   - **Exploratory Thinking** → Enhance constraints in brainstorming.  
   - **Critical Thinking** → Introduce sustainability trade-off debates.  
   - **Individual Initiative** → Embed personal accountability actions.  

### **Summary**
The module has strong problem-framing and exploratory elements but lacks explicit climate resilience integration. By embedding sustainability considerations into ideation, risk planning, and stakeholder engagement, this program can better prepare entrepreneurs for climate-adaptive business models while maintaining its core focus on innovation.

### **Implementation Plan for Climate Resilience Integration**  

Below are the structured implementation recommendations to enhance climate resilience in the **User Research Module** of the entrepreneurship training program.  

---

## **Table 1: Content Changes**  
_Adding climate resilience perspectives into key parts of the module._

| **Location** | **Current Text** | **Revised Text** | **Implementation Notes** |
|-------------|----------------|----------------|----------------|
| **Slide 13: “Interview”** | "Learn as much as you can about the other person’s morning routine. What was their favorite part? What could be improved?" | "Learn as much as you can about the other person’s morning routine. How do seasonal changes, extreme weather, or resource limitations affect their routine? What was their favorite part? What could be improved?" | **Facilitator Note:** Encourage participants to ask about local climate conditions and how they impact daily habits (e.g., extreme heat, unreliable electricity, water shortages). |
| **Slide 14: “Dig Deeper”** | "Ask why 5 times" | "Ask why 5 times. Consider external factors like environmental conditions, resource availability, or climate impacts when digging deeper." | **Facilitator Note:** Prompt participants to uncover underlying environmental constraints in their user personas. |
| **Slide 15: “Brainstorm”** | "Generate at least five creative ways to solve this problem." | "Generate at least five creative ways to solve this problem, ensuring at least one solution considers climate resilience (e.g., uses sustainable materials, reduces waste, or adapts to extreme weather)." | **Facilitator Note:** Encourage using real-world local climate challenges (e.g., frequent power outages, water conservation). |
| **Slide 16: “Build”** | "Use available materials to prototype your idea." | "Use locally sourced, recycled, or sustainable materials to prototype your idea." | **Facilitator Note:** Set up a materials station with eco-friendly prototyping options (e.g., cardboard, repurposed plastic). |
| **Slide 17: “Feedback”** | "Write down how they feel about it. Watch how they use it, misuse it, what mistakes they are making." | "Write down how they feel about it. Watch how they use it, misuse it, and assess whether the idea would still work under extreme weather conditions or resource scarcity." | **Facilitator Note:** Add a reflection question: *"How does your product/service hold up in a changing climate?"* |

---

## **Table 2: Activity Modifications**  
_Adjusting existing exercises to embed climate resilience in a natural way._

| **Activity** | **Current Format** | **Suggested Modification** | **Reasoning** |
|-------------|----------------|----------------|----------------|
| **User Interview** | Participants conduct interviews on daily routines. | Add questions about seasonal climate impacts and how users adapt (e.g., "What challenges do you face when temperatures rise above 45°C?"). | Encourages entrepreneurs to understand environmental constraints and design solutions that work in real-world conditions. |
| **Dig Deeper (5 Whys)** | Participants ask "why" five times to find root causes of a problem. | Add a *sixth why*: "How would this change if environmental conditions worsened?" | Encourages deeper thinking about long-term climate resilience and resource dependency. |
